div1.p: BUREAU OF IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION
Washington July 23, 1908.
To be returned to U.S. Immigration Service, Seattle, after serving its purpose.
Chinese Inspector in Charge, Sumas, Washington
Sir:-

Referring to the decisions rendered in May last by the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, in the two cases of Tang Tung and his wife Leung Lum Wui and Can Pon, you are informed that the Bureau has given very careful consideration to the language in which said decisions are couched, the circumstances that surrounded the cases, and the evidence developed before the Inspector in Charge and eventually placed before the Department on appeal, and has endeavored to determine just how far and in exactly what respects each of said decisions has run counter to a fair interperation of the holdings of the Supreme Court in the Sing Tuek, Ju Toy, and Chin Yow cases and the prior opinons of said court that gradually led up to the stand taken in said cases. If time permitted, the Bureau should endeavor to place its observations (or such of them as are susceptible of such use) in the form of a brief, so that they might be presented to the United States Attorney in better shape for his purposes; but the best it can do at present is to mention the points that occur to it as the result of a study of those cases and its experience in the enforcement of the Chinese exclusion law, and inclose

figure.p: 3062-0 for letter sending purposes copy & U.S. Atty

div1.p: a copy of this letter form which the United States Attorney may, perhaps, be able to select some suggestions of value.

In the first plaace it is evident that the Honorable Judge has approached these cases (as well as several others decided favorably to the Government) from a point of view diametrically opposed to the majority opinions in the Sing Tuck and Ju Toy cases; i.e., he has assumed as a premise from which to start (as Mr. Justice Brewer always does in the Supreme Court) that the person applying for admission, ostersibly an alien, and whether an alien or not, standing at our portals and knocking for admission, is as a matter of fact an American citizen -- the very claim that remains yet to be proved. This attitude, however it may be disguised in judicial language, not only does not conform to the Supreme Court decisions, but in effect shifts the burden from the shoulders on which the law as by those decisions constructed has placed it, or at least reduces the necessity that those alleging a failure to accord "due process of law" shall "affirmatively" show such failure (Ju Toy Case) to a requirement merely that they shall make a prima facie showing to that effect. "Of course, if the writ is granted the first issue to be tried is the truth of the allegations" of abuse of discretion (Chin Yow Case).

Assuming this contrary attitude as a premis from which to proceed, it is only natural that the conduct of the cases throughout should be tinged with the same error of conception and conduct; that the next step should be a detailed scrutiny of the evidence

in an effort to weigh it and accurately determine the facts --some- thing the court is not called upon to do at all until the affirmative showing of abuse has been made by the petitioner. "And, by way of caution, we mad add that jurisdiction would not established simply by proving that the Commissioner (immigration offical) and the Department of Commerce and Labor did not accept certain sworn statements as true, even though no contrary or impeaching testimony was adduced;" and "the denial of a hearing cannot be established by proving that the decision was wrong" -- by proving, actually proving affirmatively, that the decision on the facts, the weight accorded the evidence, was erroneous. (Chin Yow Case). What could be a more clear and outright assertion that, by the very nature of these cases and the circumstances out of which evidence must be gathered, on the question of fact and the weight of the evidence the adminstrative officers must be allowed absolute discretion? And this amounts, at any rate, to no more than a recognition of a variation of the general principle and idea, running through our law and system of jurisprudence, that questions of fact and of the credibility of evidence should be to the fullest extent possible to be left to the determination of those before whom the evidence is produced, who by reason of that fact are best qualified to pass upon credibility and weight.
To take upon the two cases seperatly: CASE OF TANG TUN & LEUNG LUM WUI:-

In this case the discharge of the petitioners from custody under the writ of habeas corpus is based upon two grounds: 1st, That
the Inspector in Charge was prejudiced against the petitioner Tang Tun and did not accord the evidence in his favor proper weight; and 2nd, That the appeal of the petitioners was dismissed, not by the Secretary of Commerce and Labor, but by "some officer of the Department, acting for or in place of the Secretary" who "refused to entertain the appeal and arbitrarily, without deigning to assing a reason, dismissed it."

The second reason assigned is the result of a gross misunderstanding combined with a failure to judicially notice the obvious fact that the person who signed the telegram "Murray" dismissing the appeal,was at the time of so signing and had been for several years the Assistant Secretary of Commerce and Labor, appointed as such by the President and as much by the Senate, and having full charge in the Department of all matters relating to Chinese appeals. Doubtless had the Honorable Judge not been laboring under a missapprehension on this point, he would have been slower to have assigned as a cause for the discharge of the petitioners the first reason above mentioned. The difficulty that now confronts the Government is brought about by the stipulation entered into at the time the case was submitted to the court containing the assertion that the telegram signed "Murray" was the only record covering the dismissal of appeal and not explaining the offical capacity of the signer. However, the Department could readily certify for the information of the higher court not only that the telegram was not an indication that an under offical of the Department denied privilege of appeal to the petitioners, but also that the telegram
was sent only after the appeal record had received the careful personal attention of the Assistant Secretary, and that its brief wording and signature were the result only of a practice then obtaining in the Department whereby it was understood by the Inspectors in Charge at ports of entry that a telegram so worded and so signed indicated that a review of the appeal record resulted in the affirmation of the findings of the Inspector in Charge to a sufficient extent to justify the rejection of the appellant. Thus it will be seen that in this case the Inspector in Charge and the Assistant Secretary of Commerce and Labor both considered all of the evidence presented and the assertion by the court that the decision was the result of prejudice necessarily carries the implication that the Assistant Secretary, as well as the Inspector in Charge, was actuated by such prejudice. In taking up the record and considering the weight of the evidence and passing upon the facts, thus arriving at the first reason for dismissing the petitioners, the court therefore was doing nothing more nor less than reviewing judically a decision on questions of fact rendered by the adminstrative officers clothed with exclusive jurisdiction concerning such questions. Any two persons examing evidence on a question of fact at all close are likely to reach different conclusions; and a judical officer in examining such evidence is almost certain, even unconsciously, to be governed by the strict rules of evidence applying to judicial inquiries -- the very contingency that Congress intended to avoid by placing the decision of these cases in the adminstrative officers who, by reason of their situation, the machinery at their
control, and their practial experience in the enforcement of the law are best qualified to reach a correct conclusion (at least so the Congress assumed) on such questions. Moreover, the Supreme Court has carefully guarded this point by the reiterated caution containted in the Chin Yow Case and the assertion therein that actual proof that the adminstrative decision is wrong is not sufficient to open the merits of the case in the court, much less the mere opinion of a judicial officer after reviewing the evidence that such adminstrative decision is wrong. There was no intention that the hearing should be judicially conducted, in fact the intention was the opposite as already seen, and all that is neccessary is that a fair opportunity to produce the evidence that he desired, or a fair though summary hearing, the case can proceed no farther." Chin Yow Case. On this point the latter part of the Japanese Immigrant Case (189 U. S. 86, 99-102) is not only interesting but absolutely conclusive.
CASE OF CAN PON:-

In this case all that has been said directly with respect to the first reason assigned for discharging the petitioners in the preceding case holds good. Under the Supreme Court decisions, the Honorable Judge should not have resorted to an examination of the evidence for the petitioner was born in the United States as claimed; that question was not before him in even the remotest degree. It
was his privilege and duty, of course, to examine the record and pursue the evidence with a view to determine whether "due process of law" had been observed in a necessarily summary and adminstrative, not judical, manner. If by such an examination he had reached the conclusion that a summary "due process of law" had not been accorded then, and only then, was he privilged to examine into the merits of the case. But he did even more in this case. he proceeded to have evidence taken before a referee and used that evidence to the exclusion of that presented before the administrative officers, which it was his privilege to review for the above mentioned purpose, in reaching a conclusion ostensibly as to whether there had been due process of law but actually as to whether or not the petitioner was born in the United States, and being satisfied in his own mind that the petitioner was born in this country he throws out all of the evidence taken before the adminstrative officers and holds that petitioner is entitled to be discharged. In other words, he has approached the case from the wrong end by proceeding upon the theory "that the question of prime importance in this case is whether the contestant is or is not a native born citizen of the United States" -- a question which was not before him at all. It is worthy of note in this connection that the practice followed by the Judge was that best calculated to either overthrow the evidence taken before the adminstrative officers or to explain away the discrepancies appearing therein; for when he called the witnesses before the referee and took their testimony they were, of course, fully
apprised and ample opportunity had been afforded for their coaching and preparation. Aside from any other question, the ends of justice are not likely to be met by such procedure.

In this case, as in the other, the Honorable Judge seems to have labored under a misapprehension with respect to the care exercised in the Department in handling Chinese appeals. His criticism with respect to the opinion of the Solicitor and the decision thereon of the Acting Secretary (both capacities happening in this particular case to have been filled by the same individual at the time the case was considered in the two offices, respectively) is wholly uncalled for and about as wide of the mark as anything possibly could be. In the first place he loses sight of the fact that the Solicitor of the Department is merely its legal adviser and could not in any sense whatever be said to fill "the capacity of a Solicitor adversely to the appellant." He had no interest adverse to the appellant but was only interested to ascertain from the record the facts as there shown and point out to the Secretary the application of the law to such facts. That he subsequently passed upon the case as Acting Secretary was not strange or unusual. He is designated by the President to act as Secretary on occasions when his services are such required. The practice in the Department is to have the Chinese appeals carefully reviewed by the Bureau of Immigration and Naturalization after which they are re-reviewed by the Solicitor's office and finally reach the Assistant Secretary or Acting Secretary for personal consideration, which personal consideration

they always recieve. The very fact that the same person reviewed the case in detail as Solicitor and later passed upon it as Acting Secretary is conclusive proof that in this instance the merits had the personal attention of the head of the Department -- the importance of which the court so emphatically declares. All of this can be shown by certificate of the Department if such a certificate is required and can be introduced in the higher court.

It is needless to say that none of the foregoing is intended as a criticism of the District Court, for the Bureau has the highest respect for the opinions of the Judge thereof and would not say or do anything that could be construed as disrespectful to him. It is merely an expression of views which the Bureau believes are sound, on matters which it is his privilege, of course, to regard differently. If it were not for the fact that the decisions if allowed to stand are likely to produce uncalculable bad results, the Bureau would be disposed to ask that you, the Inspector in Charge at Seattle, and the United States Attorney confer fully with Judge Hanford pointing out to him with the utmost courtesy wherein it is perceived that he is laboring under misapprehensions and assuring him of the desire of the adminstrative officers to decide all of these cases with fairness both to the Chinese and the Government. It would be all the more disposed to do this because of the Honorable Judge's attitude as indicated in the last paragraph of his decision in the Gon Ed case, which it takes to be an indication of a determination on his part not to allow his court to be used as a means whereby
the Chinese and their unscrupulous attorneys may effect their illegal ends. But the Bureau fears the effect that the decisions, especially that in the Can Pon case, might have upon other District Courts, if allowed to stand in the reports unreversed. It therefore hopes that the above argument, hastily prepared and it is realized extremely crude in construction and arrangement, may be of at least some suggestive value to the United States Attorney.

No harm could result, however, from a full discussion of the matter with Judge Hanford, even though appeals are taken from his decisions; and nothing is more useful to the Service than a thorough understanding with the Judiciary. Perhaps the United States Attorney may think it well, therefore, to at least call the Judge's attention to the manner in which he misapprehended the Department's action in the two appeal cases under discussion.

If the cases are not called for hearing in the Circuit Court of Appeals until late in the fall, and the Bureau can be of further assistance on any particular points, it will be glad to devote further time to the subject. Respectfully,
(Signed) F. E. Larned. Acting Commissioner-General.
